we afford social welfare to the in-group and not to out-groups, that's tribalism. If the group is defined by nation state or superstate is just a matter of semantics. No you are right, social welfare doesn't require sovereign national states but it does require you to divide the world into administrative sub units, if you want to call them states instead of nation states that doesn't really change the fact that social welfare demands discrimination against out-groups, which in modern terms means nations.

WRITING.TITLE: Most militarized nation in history?
WRITING.TEXT:
Sparta, Mongolia, North Korea, Prussia, Napoleonic France, 3rd reich, imperial japan... Basing militarization on proportion of total population engaged in making war, There have been a great many highly militarized societies in history. What would be your top 15?
Combat effectiveness is not what I'm looking for - spears and shields or tactical nukes rank the same in terms of how large a proportion of their respective societies are devoted to using them.

this is an incredible unfair description imo
taken into the context of his role in WWI as one of the extremely few higher-ups who was not willing to send endless waves of men to their death it's pretty clear he was trying to create some stability in a nation that had been brutally ran over at a time when american isolationism was completely dominant in US politics and the UK had sunk the french fleet and was otherwise totally incapable of fighting germany on the continent
is it really so bad to choose some semblance of statehood in france over dispersed hopeless guerilla tactics, which in turn forces harsher german occupation? (remember this was initially before the eastern front opened, too)
